channel.title: Free Pool of IPv4 Address Space Depleted
channel.description: [quote="http://www.nro.net/news/ipv4-free-pool-depleted"]Montevideo, 3 February 2011 – The Number Resource Organization (NRO) announced today that the free pool of available IPv4 addresses is now fully depleted. On Monday, January 31, the Internet Assigned Numbers Authority (IANA) allocated two blocks of IPv4 address space to APNIC, the Regional Internet Registry (RIR) for the Asia Pacific region, which triggered a global policy to allocate the remaining IANA pool equally between the five RIRs. Today IANA allocated those blocks. This means that there are no longer any IPv4 addresses available for allocation from the IANA to the five RIRs.[/quote]

item.title: Free Pool of IPv4 Address Space Depleted
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

Greeny:

Tech support is shit, yet every time I apply for a tech support job they say I’m lacking experience. Fuck off.

Even without any experience, you should be able to become a level 1 tech support guy (sounds like Scientology). All they do is go through checklists, like the ones you find via Windows Help. Anyone not completely oblivious to computers knows how to find Windows Help, if he even needs it.

Read full topic

item.title: Free Pool of IPv4 Address Space Depleted
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

My ISP posted a blog post a few weeks ago saying that basically IPv6 was coming “when it was needed” and not to worry.

In my opinion it was fucking needed 5 years ago, but at least they have it in mind I suppose.

Read full topic
item.source: Free Pool of IPv4 Address Space Depleted

item.title: Free Pool of IPv4 Address Space Depleted
item.dc:creator: @Greeny Greeny
item.description:
@Greeny wrote:

Lothy:

Only one ISP, Internode, has the infrastructure for IPv6 set up and ready to release. They’ve tested it with a few hundred power users, and they’re preparing to release it to everyone.

Actually quite impressive since no-one else is doing anything. I’m not even going to ask my ISP, if I asked about IPv6 they’d probably tell me to

“restart my modem and router”, and “if that didn’t work power everything off for 10 minutes”.

“Sorry I was asking about when IPv6 would get rolled out?”

“Your IP address is fine Mr Green, please call back if you have any problems and I’ll tell you to turn all your stuff off again” phone goes dead

Tech support is shit, yet every time I apply for a tech support job they say I’m lacking experience. Fuck off.

Read full topic

item.title: Free Pool of IPv4 Address Space Depleted
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

cumescape:

IPv6 is going to run out just like IPv4… because everyone is going to have :::1/999000 addresses.

There are enough IPv6 addresses for something like 6 devices per square meter of the entire surface of the planet earth. So no, I don’t think they will run out in our lifetimes.

Read full topic

item.title: Free Pool of IPv4 Address Space Depleted
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“sppt, post:10, topic:381063”]ARPAgeddon ftw.
It sucks that my ISP was like “HURP DURP we don’t see any problems coming the next few years” last year.
They do however have plans to rollout IPv6, so let’s hope they manage to do so before the end of the year.[/quote]

My ISP said that probably no one will ever go to IPv6. I asked them what they planned on doing then, and they said they have no plans and not to worry that it won’t be a problem for many years down the road. This is Time Warner Cable btw, ridiculous.

(I had to talk to a 3rd level tech before they even knew what IPv6 was…)

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“cooper, post:8, topic:381063”][quote author=Mopman link=topic=476878.msg3488160#msg3488160 date=1296763888]
Also, @ newty, they’re not allowed to sell allocations. I guess they could work out some under the table mutually beneficial thing with some other company, but straight out selling the addresses is not allowed.
[/quote]
Why not? Who regulates that?[/quote]

IANA I believe. They are the only ones who ‘own’ addresses.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

If you “read the damn article” you’d notice that this is just about /8 allocation to the RIR’s. It doesn’t mean we’ve run out of addresses, it’s just yet another warning sign.

Read full topic
item.source: Free Pool of IPv4 Address Space Depleted

item.title: Free Pool of IPv4 Address Space Depleted
item.dc:creator: @NewbieNewty Newty
item.description:
@NewbieNewty wrote:

From what I understand, big companies like ford, gm, and other large corporations stand to make huge dividends from this because in the early 90’s they bought millions of ipv4 addresses when they were considered limitless. Those companies have used a small portion of those addresses and can now sell them off to other companies for exponentially more then they paid for them.

Read full topic
item.source: Free Pool of IPv4 Address Space Depleted

item.title: Free Pool of IPv4 Address Space Depleted
item.dc:creator: @Greeny Greeny
item.description:
@Greeny wrote:

I don’t need to. We’ve been running out of ipv4 address for years (that’s the old news), the fact that they’ve just finished allocating them off means my above post requires 1 slight amendment.

They've just [s]nearly[/s] ran out of address to allocate to different regions.
Although there's plenty of address space left that's unused.
Is still true.

I’m not saying the topic is irrelevant, I’ll explain myself better - I’m just saying I’ve seen these news articles sprouting up all over the place for the past 2-3 years. Many suggest the internet is about to run out of address space, when it’s not. It’s just all been regionally allocated. There’s an awful lot of unused addresses still.

The real news here is the fact that the industry has been evading the move to IPv6 for so long.

Read full topic

Although there’s plenty of address space left that’s unused. They’ve just nearly ran out of address to allocate to different regions.
